I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed project will support the Government of the People’s Republic of China’s 
efforts to address the escalating environmental deterioration and stress in the dryland ecosystems 
and loess areas along the Silk Road. It will seek to deliver outcomes that synthesize the lessons 
learned and forge multi-dimensional interventions for integrated grassland, wetland, and forested 
areas restoration and management. A phased approach, supported by successful demonstration 
sites, are integral to the package of interventions to build awareness of the nature of the problems 
and the solutions being proposed. The government has requested for a $200.0 million loan from 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to finance an ecological protection and rehabilitation project 
in Gansu, Shaanxi, and Qinghai provinces. The project will be aligned with the following impacts: 
(i)  ecological  restoration  and  environmental  governance  in  key  regions  crucial  to  national 
ecological security promoted; and (ii) ecological protection and restoration projects in order to 
create more jobs and raise incomes implemented, as envisaged in the Thirteenth Five-Year Plan 
for Economic and Social Development of the PRC, 2016–2020. The project will have three 
outputs: (i) degradation of forests, wetlands, and grasslands in the loess areas arrested and 
reversed; (ii) livelihood diversification in loess areas implemented; and (iii) Institutional capacity 
for integrated ecosystem management strengthened. These outputs will result in the following 
outcome: ecological resilience and rural livelihood security in the loess areas enhanced. The 
proposed project is included in ADB’s lending program for 2020.1 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The government requested ADB to assist in preparing the Silk Road Ecological Protection 
and Rehabilitation Project covering three provinces. The initial project parameters, including 
scope, implementation arrangements, and financing amount were confirmed with the government 
during a reconnaissance mission fielded on 6–10 August 2018.2  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
3.  Output  1:  Sector assessment conducted, and feasibility of the ensuing project 
assessed. This output will: (i) conduct a comprehensive sector assessment including identification 
of policy and institutional gaps and needs; (ii) assess the technical, economic, and financial 
feasibility of project interventions; (iii) review safeguard requirements; (iii) conduct social survey, 
consultations and analyses, and prepare measures on poverty, social, and gender aspects; and 
(iv) assist the executing agency in revising domestic feasibility studies and improving documents 
in line with ADB’s and the government’s requirements. The inception report will be prepared as 
part of this output covering these key parameters. 
  
4.  Output 2: Project design and documents for the ensuing loan prepared.  This output 
will (i) finalize the project design, including scope and core subproject details, project cost estimates, 
and detailed implementation arrangements including coordination between project provinces; (ii) 
assist in preparing project documents, including ADB’s draft report and recommendation of the 
President, project administration manual, and key linked documents, including due diligence 
reports and resettlement framework and/or plans,  poverty and social analysis reports, initial 
 
1 ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2018–2020. Manila.

environmental examination and/or environmental assessment review framework, climate risk 
vulnerability assessments and specific climate change modeling and assessments in the project 
areas,  ethnic minorities  development  framework  or  plan,  gender  action  plan,  financial  and 
economic analysis report, financial management capacity assessment and procurement capacity 
risk assessment of the executing agency. An interim report will be finalized covering all the project 
due diligence and design requirements of ADB and the government. 
 
5.  Output  3:  Institutional  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies 
improved. A detailed institutional and implementation capacity and training needs assessment will 
be conducted to develop capacity for project implementation. Initial procurement and financial 
management capacity training will be conducted with the executing and implementing agencies to 
orient them on ADB procedures and requirements. The final technical assistance report will be part 
of  this  output  and  form  the  basis  for  the  project  fact-finding  mission  and  memorandum  of 
understanding to be agreed between the government and ADB. Advance action/start-up support 
for continued capacity strengthening of the executing and implementing agencies will be provided 
under this output extending to the initial loan implementation period.

C.  Cost and Financing  
 
7.  The technical assistance (TA) is estimated to cost $967,200, of which (i) $800,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources),

3 
and (ii) $167,200 will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund3 and administered 
by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
  
8.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, domestic 
transportation, data collection, logistic support in arranging workshops and field visits, and other 
in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will administer the TA. The State Forestry and Grassland Administration will be the 
executing agency and will have a national project management office that will coordinate with 
ADB and provide guidance to the implementation agencies established in the district and county 
governments in Gansu, Qinghai, and Shaanxi provinces under the Provincial Forestry and 
Grassland Department. The TA will be implemented tentatively from February 2019 to November 
2020. Disbursement under the TA will be in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
